name: zirconium and hafnium tetrachloride production, from zircon | zirconium tetrachloride | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/26602/documentation

This dataset refers to the production of 1 kg of nuclear-grade (hafnium-free) zirconium tetrachloride and 0.019091 kg of hafnium tetrachloride produced from zircon by applying the carbochlorination process (Zr(Hf)SiO4 + 4C + 4Cl2 → Zr(Hf)Cl4 + SiCl4 + 4CO), which produces the bundled zirconium & hafnium tetrachloride (Zr(Hf)Cl4) and then the extractive distillation process, which separates the bundled Zr(Hf)Cl4 into pure ZrCl4 and HfCl4 in the US. Since the US is a major producer of pure zirconium & hafnium metal, it is assumed that the US is also a major producer of zirconium and hafnium tetrachloride, representing approximately 26.7% of the global ZrCl4 production.;In the present dataset, there are two reference products (zirconium and hafnium tetrachloride), thus allocation (subdivision) of the Life Cycle Inventory (LCI) is required. The allocation is based on metal mass content in zirconium and hafnium tetrachloride. For more information, consult the ''Modelling & Administrative'' section.;Due to lack of data regarding the carbochlorination process of zircon sand, data were taken from the Gao et al. (2018) publication that contains data on the carbochlorination process of titanium. Exception to this are the inputs of zircon sand, petroleum coke, and chlorine, and the outputs of silicon tetrachloride and carbon monoxide emissions. These exchanges were calculated based on the stoichiometric equation that governs the carbochlorination process (for more information consult the individual exchange comments). Data regarding the extractive distillation process, were taken from the Minh et al. (2015) publication.  ;Reference 1: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.;Reference 2: Minh, L. Q., Long, N. V. D., Duong, P. L. T., Jung, Y., Bahadori, A., & Lee, M. (2015). Design of an Extractive Distillation Column for the Environmentally Benign Separation of Zirconium and Hafnium Tetrachloride for Nuclear Power Reactor Applications. Energies, 8(9), 10354-10369.

The activity starts with the processing of zircon. According to USGS, 54% of zircon in US is supplied from South Africa and 19% from Australia.

Source: <https://pubs.usgs.gov/periodicals/mcs2022/mcs2022-zirconium-hafnium.pdf> 


The activity ends with the production of nuclear-grade zirconium  tetrachloride and hafnium tetrachloride, 

No allocation is applied.

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data are considered representative of current production practices.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Dataset valid for the entire corresponding region. Since USA is a major producer of pure zirconium & hafnium metal, it is assumed that USA is also the major producer of zirconium and hafnium tetrachloride.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: After the production of the zircon sand, it enters the fluidized bed carbochlorinator, where petroleum coke and chlorine gas react with the zircon sand at 1200°C producing bundled zirconium-hafnium-silicon tetrachlorides and carbon monoxide. The stoichiometric equation is the following; ZrSiO4 ,(HfSiO4 ) + 4 Cl2 + 4 C → ZrCl4 + SiCl4 ,(HfCl4 ) + 4 CO. Afterwards, the bundle product is condensed to remove silicon tetrachloride, since it condenses to higher temperatures than Zr-Hf tetrachlorides. The bundled Zr-Hf product condenses and enters the Zr-Hf separation process. ;The composition of the bundled product is assumed to be 98.4% ZrCl4 and 1.6% HfCl4. In the extractive distillation process, a counter flow technique with a column of molten salt is utilized for the separation of the chlorides. During 1 hour of operation, 23405.1 kg of bundled Zr-Hf tetrachlorides enter the molten-salt-based column (consisting of NaCl and KCl with 8:29 M) from the top. The bundled chloride dissolve creating a molten salt system (34.0 mol% NaCl and KCl (8:29 M); 66.0 mol% ZrCl4 and HfCl4). From the top of the column the solvents are circulated to the bottom, while the zirconium-hafnium chloride fumes follow the opposite direction. The rising fumes are progressively enriched in hafnium chlorides and are extracted from the top of the column (distillate stream) while the flow going down is enriched producing nuclear-grade zirconium tetrachlorides, which are condensed and extracted from the bottom stream.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
Approximation of the carbochlorination process of zirconium tetrachloride with the carbochlorination process of titanium tetrachloride (for more information about which data were taken from the titanium tetrachloride production process consult the sampling procedure). There are mostly 2 zirconium - hafnium separation processes used around the world: i) liquid-liquid extraction by using methyl isobutyl ketone (MIBK) as solving agent (dominant process in the USA), or extractive distillation with molten potassium chloroaluminate (KAlCl4) (dominant process in France). Due to lack of quantitative information about the inputs and outputs of these processes, data regarding the zirconium - hafnium separation process through extractive distillation by using sodium & potassium chloride was considered here, based on the Minh et al. (2015) publication.The uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.

Reference: Minh, L. Q., Long, N. V. D., Duong, P. L. T., Jung, Y., Bahadori, A., & Lee, M. (2015). Design of an Extractive Distillation Column for the Environmentally Benign Separation of Zirconium and Hafnium Tetrachloride for Nuclear Power Reactor Applications. Energies, 8(9), 10354-10369.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
For the carbochlorination process of zircon: Due to absence of data for the inputs and outputs during the production of zirconium & hafnium tetrachloride, the inputs and outputs of the titanium tetrachloride production dataset is assumed here as the best available representation, since titanium tetrachloride is also produced through the carbochlorination of titanium slag/ilmenite concentrate (first step of the Kroll process). The inputs and outputs (byproducts & emissions) for the titanium carbochlorination process were taken from the Gao et al. (2018) publication. Exception to this is the input of total zircon and the output of silicon tetrachloride, whose calculation was solely based on the stoichiometric equation that governs the carbochlorination process (Zr(Hf)SiO4 + 4C + 4Cl2 → Zr(Hf)Cl4 + SiCl4 + 4CO). The input of petroleum coke was calculated considering not only the abovementioned stoichiometric equation but also the fact that petroleum coke is added in excess (53.08% - as in the titanium carbochlorination process) to account for the inefficiency in the reaction. Because of this the carbon monoxide emissions were calculated based on carbon balance of the entire process, without considering the stoichiometric reaction of the process. 

All the abovementioned exchanges, have been readjusted to correspond to the production of 1 kg of nuclear-grade zirconium tetrachloride, by multiplying by 1.1956, since 1.1956 kg of Zr(Hf)Cl4 is required in the extractive distillation process in order to produce 1 kg of nuclear-grade (hafnium-free) ZrCl4 (for more information consult the individual exchange comments).

In addition, during the production of zirconium & hafnium sponge through the Kroll process, magnesium chloride is produced as a byproduct, which undergoes electrolysis (MgCl2 → Mg + Cl2) in order to obtain Mg that is fed back to the zirconium & hafnium sponge production process and Cl2 that is fed back to the zirconium and hafnium tetrachloride production process. Therefore, there is the recovered chlorine that is reused in this process and the non-recovered amount that is calculated by subtracting the recovered amount from the stoichiometrically required amount (consult the respective exchange comments for analytical calculation).

For the extractive distillation process: All data relevent to the extractive distillation process (electricity consumption, zirconium & hafnium tetrachloride outputs) were taken from the Minh et al. (2015) publication. The sodium & potassium chloride inputs have not been considered because they are recovered from the stripper units at the end of the process and then returned back to the feed storage, thus staying within the boundaries of the system. 

Due to the fact that that there are two reference products in this dataset (zirconium & hafnium tetrachloride), subdivision of the exchange amounts between zirconium tetrachloride and the hafnium tetrachloride is required first. This subdivision is based on the shares of metal mass contained in zirconium tetrachloride and hafnium tetrachloride. The zirconium metal mass in zirconium tetrachloride is roughly 0.39148 kg while the hafnium metal mass in hafnium tetrachloride is roughly 0.01064 kg. The resulting fractions for the subdivision are approximately 97.354% and 2.646%, meaning that 97.354% of the exchanges are allocated to zirconium tetrachloride production and the remaining 2.645% are allocated to hafnium tetrachloride production. 

Reference 1: Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.

Reference 2: Minh, L. Q., Long, N. V. D., Duong, P. L. T., Jung, Y., Bahadori, A., & Lee, M. (2015). Design of an Extractive Distillation Column for the Environmentally Benign Separation of Zirconium and Hafnium Tetrachloride for Nuclear Power Reactor Applications. Energies, 8(9), 10354-10369.

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the amount of recycled chlorine - obtained during the electrolysis of magnesium chloride - that is used during the production of 1 kg of zirconium tetrachloride and 0.019091 kg of hafnium tetrachloride. 

The amount of recycled chlorine is calculated based on the following assumptions:


i)	During the production of zirconium and hafnium sponge, 2.0386 and 1.0419 kg of magnesium chloride are produced as a byproduct respectively (consult the datasets ''zirconium sponge production, from zirconium tetrachloride'' & ''hafnium sponge production, from hafnium tetrachloride''  for more information). The abovementioned amounts are sent to the electrolysis process (MgCl2 → Mg + Cl2) in order to obtain magnesium that is fed back to the respective sponge production process and chlorine that is fed back to the zirconium and hafnium tetrachloride production process. 

ii)	Based on the respective electrolysis datasets (''electrolysis of magnesium chloride, from zirconium sponge production'' & ''electrolysis of magnesium chloride, from hafnium sponge production''), 0.345552 kg of chlorine per kg of magnesium chloride is recovered. Therefore, the amount of chlorine per kg Zr and Hf sponge is 0.345552*2.0386 and 0.345552*1.0419 respectively. 

iii)	Stoichiometrically, 2.5545 kg of ZrCl4 and 1.7945 kg of HfCl4 are required for the production of 1 kg of Zr and Hf sponge respectively.

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the amount of zircon supplied from Australia that is used for the production of 1 kg of zirconium tetrachloride and 0.019091 kg of hafnium tetrachloride. This amount is calculated by multiplying the total amount of zircon required for the production of 1 kg of zirconium tetrachloride and 0.019091 kg of hafnium tetrachloride by the share of zircon supplied from Australia (19% - according to USGS).

The total amount of zircon required as an input is calculated based on the following facts:

i)	the stoichiometric equation of the carbochlorination process: Zr(Hf)SiO4 + 4C + 4Cl2 → Zr(Hf)Cl4 + SiCl4 + 4CO, which means that for the production of 1 kg of Zr(Hf)Cl4 (zirconium tetrachloride bundled with hafnium tetrachloride), 0.786604 kg of zircon are required as input. 

ii)	1.1956 kg of Zr(Hf)Cl4 is required in the extractive distillation process in order to produce 1 kg of nuclear-grade hafnium-free ZrCl4, according to the Minh et al (2015) publication. 

An activity link has been set in order to ensure zircon is supplied from Australia.

Reference: Minh, L. Q., Long, N. V. D., Duong, P. L. T., Jung, Y., Bahadori, A., & Lee, M. (2015). Design of an Extractive Distillation Column for the Environmentally Benign Separation of Zirconium and Hafnium Tetrachloride for Nuclear Power Reactor Applications. Energies, 8(9), 10354-10369).

Source: <https://pubs.usgs.gov/periodicals/mcs2022/mcs2022-zirconium-hafnium.pdf$>

The total electricity consumption is the sum of the electricity consumption during the carbochlorination process and the electricity consumption during the extractive distillation process. For the carbochlorination process the following strategy is applied: 

Due to absence of data for further inputs required during the carbochlorination of zircon, any additional inputs reported in the titanium tetrachloride production dataset are assumed here as the best available representation, since titanium tetrachloride is also produced through the carbochlorination of titanium dioxide (first step of the Kroll process). As a consequence, the description provided below (refering to the production of 1 kg of titanium tetrachloride) represents also the respective inputs during the production of 1 kg of Zr(Hf)Cl4 (zirconium tetrachloride bundled with hafnium tetrachloride). The original value reported is multiplied by the amount of Zr(Hf)Cl4 required per kg of ZrCl4 (1.1956 kg - consult the respective parameter), since 1.1956 kg of Zr(Hf)Cl4 is required in the extractive distillation process in order to produce 1 kg of nuclear-grade hafnium-free ZrCl4, according to Minh et al (2015) publication. 

The original description from the titanium tetrachloride production dataset: 

[The original amount of electricity required in the chlorination and refining process is 2550 kWh and represents the amount required for the production of 1 metric ton of titanium sponge. This value was taken from Table 2 of the Gao et al (2018) publication. This value was adjusted to represent the production of 1 kg of TiCl4  (by dividing by 1000 and by dividing again by 3.9626 based on the fact that for the production of 1 kg of Ti sponge, 3.9626 kg of TiCl4 are needed - TiCl4 + 2Mg → Ti + 2MgCl2  more information on the titanium sponge production dataset about this equation).]

For the extractive distillation process the following applies: The electricity consumption during the extractive distillation process is the sum of electricity of required in the reboiler (1222 kWh) and the condenser (1117 kWh), assuming 1 hour of operation. The sum is then divided by 19576.36, since 19576.36 kg of purified zirconium tetrachloride are produced during 1 hour of operation. Those values for the extractive distillation process are based in figure 4 of the Minh et al (2015) publication. 

Reference 1: Minh, L. Q., Long, N. V. D., Duong, P. L. T., Jung, Y., Bahadori, A., & Lee, M. (2015). Design of an Extractive Distillation Column for the Environmentally Benign Separation of Zirconium and Hafnium Tetrachloride for Nuclear Power Reactor Applications. Energies, 8(9), 10354-10369.

[This exchange represents the amount of heat produced from the combustion of hard coal (3530 kg) and crude oil (851 kg) in the chlorination and refining process for the production of 1 metric ton of titanium sponge. The values in parentheses are taken from Table 2 of the Gao et al (2018) publication. These values were first adjusted to represent the production of 1 kg of TiCl4 (by dividing by 1000 and by diving again by 3.9626 based on the fact that for the production of 1 kg of Ti sponge, 3.9626 kg of TiCl4 are needed - TiCl4 + 2Mg → Ti + 2MgCl2 - more information on the titanium sponge production dataset). Therefore the amounts of hard coal and crude oil required per 1 kg of TiCl4 are 0.890823497 kg and 0.214756599 kg respectively.
The thermal energy from each source is calculated by multiplying the gross calorific value of each fuel (45.8 MJ/kg for crude oil and 30.4 MJ/kg for hard coal according to Table 5.1, chapter 5.6.3, page 35 of the data quality guidelines of Ecoinvent version 3) with the amount of each fuel as mentioned above. The thermal energies from each source are summed to obtain the reported value.]


Reference 1: Minh, L. Q., Long, N. V. D., Duong, P. L. T., Jung, Y., Bahadori, A., & Lee, M. (2015). Design of an Extractive Distillation Column for the Environmentally Benign Separation of Zirconium and Hafnium Tetrachloride for Nuclear Power Reactor Applications. Energies, 8(9), 10354-10369.

The amount of petroleum coke required as an input is calculated based on the following facts: 

i)	the stoichiometric equation of the carbochlorination process: Zr(Hf)SiO4 + 4C + 4Cl2 → Zr(Hf)Cl4 + SiCl4 + 4CO, which means that for the production of 1 kg of Zr(Hf)Cl4 (zirconium tetrachloride bundled with hafnium tetrachloride), 0.20616 kg of carbon are required as input. 

ii)	1.1956 kg of Zr(Hf)Cl4 is required in the extractive distillation process in order to produce 1 kg of nuclear-grade hafnium-free ZrCl4, according to the Minh et al (2015) publication.

iii)	the carbon content of petroleum coke is 0.885 (see exchange properties of petroleum coke). 

iv)	In the carbochlorination process for titanium sponge production, nearly 53.08% of petroleum coke is added in excess according to Gao et al (2018). Due to lack of data and since Zirconium is produced also through the Kroll process (with the first sub process being the carbochlorination process), it is assumed that the petroleum coke is also added in excess (extra 53.08% of the stoichiometric input).

Reference 1: Minh, L. Q., Long, N. V. D., Duong, P. L. T., Jung, Y., Bahadori, A., & Lee, M. (2015). Design of an Extractive Distillation Column for the Environmentally Benign Separation of Zirconium and Hafnium Tetrachloride for Nuclear Power Reactor Applications. Energies, 8(9), 10354-10369.

This value was first adjusted to represent the production of 1 kg of TiCl4  (by dividing by 1000 and by dividing again by 3.9626 based on the fact that for the production of 1 kg of Ti sponge, 3.9626 kg of TiCl4 are needed - TiCl4 + 2Mg → Ti + 2MgCl2 - more information on the titanium sponge production dataset about this equation). The gross calorific value of the natural gas is 40.3 MJ/m3, and is taken from the data quality Guidelines of Ecoinvent version 3, page 36.]

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the amount of zircon supplied from South Africa that is used for the production of 1 kg of zirconium tetrachloride and 0.019091 kg of hafnium tetrachloride. This amount is calculated by multiplying the total amount of zircon required for the production of 1 kg of zirconium tetrachloride and 0.019091 kg of hafnium tetrachloride by the share of zircon supplied from South Africa (54% - according to USGS).

The total amount of zircon required as an input is calculated based on the following facts:

i)	the stoichiometric equation of the carbochlorination process: Zr(Hf)SiO4 + 4C + 4Cl2 → Zr(Hf)Cl4 + SiCl4 + 4CO, which means that for the production of 1 kg of Zr(Hf)Cl4 (zirconium tetrachloride bundled with hafnium tetrachloride), 0.786604 kg of zircon are required as input. 

ii)	1.1956 kg of Zr(Hf)Cl4 is required in the extractive distillation process in order to produce 1 kg of nuclear-grade hafnium-free ZrCl4, according to the Minh et al (2015) publication. 

An activity link has been set in order to ensure zircon is supplied from South Africa.

Reference: Minh, L. Q., Long, N. V. D., Duong, P. L. T., Jung, Y., Bahadori, A., & Lee, M. (2015). Design of an Extractive Distillation Column for the Environmentally Benign Separation of Zirconium and Hafnium Tetrachloride for Nuclear Power Reactor Applications. Energies, 8(9), 10354-10369).

Source: https://pubs.usgs.gov/periodicals/mcs2022/mcs2022-zirconium-hafnium.pdf

exchanges.description: This exchange represents the amount of carbon monoxide emissions during the production of 1 kg of zirconium tetrachloride and 0.019091 kg of hafnium tetrachloride. The amount of carbon monoxide emissions is calculated based on carbon balance of the entire process.

This exchange represents the amount of non-recovered Cl2 that must be added separately in order to cover the stoichiometric amount that is required during the zirconium and hafnium tetrachloride production process. The stoichiometric amount of Cl2 is based on the following equation that describes the carbochlorination of Zr(Hf)Cl4 (zirconium tetrachloride bundled with hafnium tetrachloride): Zr(Hf)SiO4 + 4C + 4Cl2 → Zr(Hf)Cl4 + SiCl4 + 4CO, which means that for the production of 1 kg of Zr(Hf)Cl4, 1.217 kg of Cl2 is required as input. This value is multiplied by the amount of Zr(Hf)Cl4 required per kg of ZrCl4 (1.1956 kg - consult the respective parameter), since 1.1956 kg of Zr(Hf)Cl4 is required in the extractive distillation process in order to produce 1 kg of nuclear-grade hafnium-free ZrCl4, according to Minh et al (2015) publication, resulting in 1.455 kg of Cl2 per kg ZrCl4. 

However, approximately 0.2795 kg of Cl2 is recycled (consult ''chlorine, for reuse in zirconium and hafnium tetrachloride production'' exchange comment), meaning that the amount of non-recovered Cl2 is calculated by subtracting the amount of recovered Cl2 (0.2795 kg) from the stoichiometric amount of Cl2 (1.455 kg).

Finally, the liquid chlorine is assumed as input instead of gaseous, since it is usually transported in liquid form which requires compression that is not considered in the gaseous chlorine exchange.

Reference: Minh, L. Q., Long, N. V. D., Duong, P. L. T., Jung, Y., Bahadori, A., & Lee, M. (2015). Design of an Extractive Distillation Column for the Environmentally Benign Separation of Zirconium and Hafnium Tetrachloride for Nuclear Power Reactor Applications. Energies, 8(9), 10354-10369).
